title: 113_hr2588
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fulfilling Our Responsibility for Efficient and Sustainable Timber Supply Act of 2013" or the "FORESTS Act of 2013". Stewardship end result contracting authority is granted. The Department of the Interior Appropriations Act of 1999 is extended until September 30, 2023. Contract durations are increased to 20 years from 10 years, and timber sale contract authority is clarified. The Department of the Interior Appropriations Act of 1999 is extended until September 30, 2023, increasing contract durations to 20 years from 10 years. The timber sale contract authority applies to the timber sale. Subsection (c) is amended to include new provisions regarding cancellation or termination costs for multiyear stewardship contracts. The Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior are not required to cover these costs until the contract is cancelled or terminated, and funding sources for these costs are specified. The Secretary may use appropriations originally available for the contract, current procurement funds, or specific funds for payments. In cases of Anti-Deficiency Act violations, the Secretary can request supplemental appropriations or permanent funds. Payments to Counties: 25 percent of timber sale receipts from contracts under this section will be paid to the county where the receipts are from, in addition to other payments under title 31, United States Code. SEC. 3. Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management cooperation. Definitions in this section include "eligible State" as a state with National Forest System or Bureau of Land Management land, "Federal land" as National Forest System or public lands, and "Secretary concerned" as the Secretary of Agriculture for National Forest System land and the Secretary of the Interior for public lands. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Bureau of Land Management, may enter into cooperative agreements with State Foresters to provide forest, rangeland, and watershed services on Federal lands in eligible States. The State Forester is the head of a State agency overseeing State forestry programs. The Secretary of the Interior can partner with State Foresters to offer forest, rangeland, and watershed services on Federal lands in eligible States. These services include activities like treating insect-infected forests, reducing hazardous fuels, and improving forest health. State Foresters may act as agents under cooperative agreements or contracts. State Foresters can serve as agents for the Secretary concerned in providing restoration, management, and protection services on Federal lands. They may enter into subcontracts to carry out these services under cooperative agreements or contracts. State Foresters can provide restoration, management, and protection services on Federal lands under cooperative agreements or contracts. Timber sales regulations and NEPA responsibilities are exempt for services performed under these agreements. The services will be carried out on a project-to-project basis under existing authorities of the Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management. The authority for State Foresters to provide services on Federal lands under cooperative agreements or contracts will end on September 30, 2023, and these agreements cannot exceed 20 years in duration.
